content.description:
This climb can start either from just inside the cave, or on the lower angle face just around the right side. In either case, proceed to the first bolt, and straight up to the second. The move after the second bolt is the crux, a high foot to the ledge on the left followed by a balancy leaning move left will get you through. Proceed up the rail to the third bolt, at which point you can use features on the right edge of the climb to proceed. There is a top anchor at this location, clip the right side of it with a quickdraw and proceed up toward the tree. The actual finish is the anchor below tree of life

This route goes up the face just to the right side of 'Tree of Life', which is the cave to the right of the main wall.
This route has two top anchors, one used for top roping and one shared with 'Tree of Life' for the full climb. It can be climbed with 5 draws to get to the second top anchor. A rappel can be rigged off of larger trees further back on the cliff to rig this as a top rope climb without leading it first, however if you go this route be mindful of the swing off the right side during your rappel.

Fun climb where the start may be the crux. Head up and keep left of the crack... or play with the crack for a more interesting climb.

One of the most easterly climbs. The beginning should look more barren then the other climbs around. Also, about 3/4 of the way up should be a crack system.
Top anchors.

Great ledges after you get past the start.

To the right of Babette.
Anchors at top.

Series of small ledges


5 bolts, anchors and rap rings

climbs.name: Bootherium Bombifrons
climbs.fa: Sport bolted in Summer of 2017, Charles Kalinsky and Greg Barrett

content.description:
Slippery start with challenging hands off the ground. Work to the right and get your feet up. Move back left to the left facing arete. Stem and jug your way to the finish.

thrid line from the left-prow. 
5 bolts

Follow the crack where Crucifix starts but instead of heading straight up head right to the arete following the crack system to the top of the cliff.

Anchors at top

Head up the slippery 5.9 climbing, involving lay-backs and ledges. Three quarters of the way up you reach the right facing side pull. Head up this to obtain the 5.11a climbing. Clip two bolts and head right onto some crimps. The crux is going from here up to the good ledge at the top. Left foot on the previously good flake for your hand, push up to reach a really terrible hold for your left hand, push up higher, then bump up to the good ledge with your left hand. Mantle up!

This is the obviously beautiful line.
Cams, tcus, and some nuts. Anchors at top.
Head up the slippery 5.9 climbing, involving lay-backs and ledges. Three quarters of the way up you reach the right facing side pull. Head up this to obtain the 5.11a climbing. Clip two bolts and head right onto some crimps. The crux is going from here up to the good ledge at the top. Left foot on the previously good flake for your hand, push up to reach a really terrible hold for your left hand, push up higher, then bump up to the good ledge with your left hand. Mantle up!
This is the obviously beautiful line.
Cams, tcus, and some nuts. Anchors at top.

climbs.name: Heretic/ Arête
climbs.fa: First bolted ascent by Alain Dallaire August 2009

content.description:
Start our right and move onto the face left using crimps. Clip the first bolt and move up and left to the arete. Use the arete to hug your way up the rest of the route. Look for hidden holds around left.

Around the corner from Crucifix. It starts on slab moves far right. If you're not familiar, stick clip the first bolt. OR walk around and set-up a top rope.
5 bolts, anchors at top.

This line has now been bolted for lead (4 bolts) and has a ring bolt anchor to quickly clean. The bolted line generally takes goes straight up the middle with the option of moving either right or left depending on which moves you'd like to try. The top rope anchors remain for people who'd like to set up from above.


This is the obvious route on the north side of the canyon.

Top anchors for top rope set-up. Otherwise 3 bolts for leading.

Follow the flake up. Takes good pro. Hard to find protection when you step out of the crack and step right onto the ledge. Pop a tcu under the right-most flake and head straight up from the ledge.

This is the middle of the three short trad routes right when you hike down into the canyon.

No anchors at the top. You'll need to sling the tree.

Short, small holds face climbing. 

Up the canyon a short ways. Can be seen from the start of Heretic. 
Anchors at top

Really fun trad route. Start stemming off the two faces of the dihedral. Head right using underclings to place your first piece. Use a side-pull to head up and place another piece. Side-pull some more until you reach a really good horn. Place more gear, and head up and over this horn. Home free. Make your way right up to the tree anchor.

This is an overhanging route to the right of the top-rope climbs.
Brings cams. Tree anchor at top. There is also a bolted top anchor below the birch tree.

Bolted route on the arete between Crucifix and Heretic

Shares anchor with either Crucifix or Heretic

A single bolt addition that utilizes the start of the left-hand 5.7. A long sling on the third bolt facilitates a step right to positive holds along the outside edge of the arête. A piece of gear in the small crack system above can help protect some strong moves over the blocks and exit. This is a harder variation of the route. 

See topo. 
Standard Rack

Moderate crux at the first bulge. Really solid finger locks will help you move past it and onto the slab; gear in the obvious places and not behind the cracked hold. A very contrived but pleasant exit is to follow the crack system off the last ledge up the slightly impending crack to gain the anchor –well back; worth doing.

Left of the Crucifix head wall. 
Standard Rack

Head up the broken flake. Everything should be very straight-forward.

Left-most trad route right at the bottom of the hike when you enter the canyon on the north side.

Takes good pro. No anchors at top, you'll need to sling the tree.

Around the corner on the main wall of grand central station.

Anchors at top

Easy trad route...

Right most trad route when you first hike into the canyon on the north side.

No anchors at the top. You'll need to sling the tree.

Sunny in the afternoon. Can be buggy in the summer. Most crowded area in the Yukon. Great place to set up top-ropes and learn how to climb. Alpine Club of Canada (ACC) has climbing nights here on Wednesdays. Granite.
